;美国国务卿安东尼·布林肯拖延已久的北京之行终于来了。尽管这次访问的乐观情绪可以预见——双方同意加强民间交流并承诺继续对话——但它对化解美国和中国之间日益紧张的冲突几乎没有起到任何作用。

;

;鉴于最近两个超级大国的军舰在台湾海峡和南中国海的飞机险些相撞，未能重新建立军事联系尤其令人担忧。更不用说报道中的中国在古巴的监视活动，这与引发 1962 年古巴导弹危机（冷战最可怕的时刻之一）的事件有着惊人的相似之处。意外冲突的风险仍然很高。

;

;根本问题是过度依赖个性化外交。是的，这在美中关系的早期发挥了至关重要的作用。美国总统理查德·尼克松 (Richard Nixon) 1972 年历史性的中国之行不仅仅是舞台表演，也是旨在三角剖分苏联的决定性战略举措。多层的个人关系有助于打破冷战中的权力平衡：尼克松和毛泽东处于顶层，亨利·基辛格和周恩来的支持下制定了美中接触的细节。

;

;但是那些日子已经结束了。个性化外交已经不再有用。由于美中关系掌握在政治上受限、脸皮薄的领导人手中，两个超级大国之间的争端变得极其难以解决。两位领导人都不能被视为软弱。现在，解决冲突更多的是看面子，而不是大战略。

;

;例如，习近平主席在与布林肯短暂的 35 分钟会面中坚持坐在谈判桌的首位，让美国高层外交官的态度绝对是顺从的。布林肯刚离开中国，美国总统乔·拜登就将这位中国领导人称为独裁者，进一步激化了中国的敏感度。

;

;这种做法不再有效，因为外交的合法性来源于国内政治。在美国方面，早在布林肯踏上北京之前，恶毒的反华情绪就束缚了他的手脚。美国众议员、新任众议院中国问题特别委员会主席、共和党人迈克·加拉格尔(Mike Gallagher)厚颜无耻地将美国的中国问题归咎于接触，他在CNBC和《华尔街日报》上辩称，“面对外国势力，接触必然导致绥靖政策”。不幸的是，加拉格尔代表了华盛顿强烈的反华共识，这让布林肯几乎没有选择。两党对这种极端观点的支持几乎排除了美国任何创造性外交的可能性。

;

;尽管中国实行一党制，但国内政治考虑同样重要。习近平权力的合法性取决于他所谓的“中国梦”，即“中华民族伟大复兴”。然而，如果没有持续的经济增长，习近平就有可能违背这一承诺，并面临公众和共产党的愤怒浪潮。

;

;这使得中国的增长不足尤其令人担忧。尽管广泛预期的刺激措施可以缓解近期经济压力，但人​​口和生产率不利因素的共同作用对于中长期增长前景来说问题更大。再加上与美国及其盟友的持续冲突导致的经济增长被放弃，毫无疑问，中国政治受到国家不断增加的“复兴赤字”的严格限制。

;

;中国无力承担观望经济刺激

;

;脆弱的自我只会加剧问题。修辞失误、舞台技巧和谩骂都被夸大了。当领导人缺乏解决冲突所需的强硬态度时，个性化外交的一触即发的反应就会适得其反。

;

;迫切需要一种新的方法。转向更加制度化的参与模式将使冲突解决不再由反应过度、政治受限的领导人掌控。这意味着重新设计中美接触的架构，使其更加注重流程，在工作组层面纳入更多的技术专长，并更多地关注共同解决问题的战略。

;

;我的建议美中秘书处远远超出了早期机构接触的尝试——即战略与经济对话和商贸联委会。这两项努力都未能阻止当前的冲突，最终被特朗普政府取消，拜登也选择不再重启这些举措。但这是因为他们在为关系管理提供永久、强大的框架方面做得还不够。

;

;像大多数人一样，我对解决两个强国之间的多个棘手问题的官僚方法持怀疑态度。华盛顿共识认为，长期以来，中国人更喜欢谈论而不是行动，喜欢过程而不是遵守，喜欢拖延而不是妥协。有人认为，新的官僚机构会增加解决对比体系之间根本分歧这一本已具有挑战性的任务的复杂性和决策层次。取得进展仍然很困难。

;

;尽管如此，更加制度化的方法比当前的政治化、个性化外交更可取。 50 年前行之有效的方法在今天已经行不通了。两国的背景非常不同。解决冲突需要的不仅仅是近代尼克松访华。

;

;个人化外交在解决美中冲突方面已走进死胡同。摆脱紧张局势升级的泥潭需要新的参与架构。中美秘书处是在为时已晚之前解决冲突的漫长而艰巨的道路上的最佳选择。

;

;瓦格纳集团负责人叶夫根尼·普里戈任上周旨在拘留俄罗斯军方首脑据《华尔街日报》周三报道，他们很早就发现了他计划的叛乱，并避免了被抓。

;

;该报援引西方官员的话说，普里戈任试图抓捕他的主要竞争对手、俄罗斯国防部长谢尔盖·绍伊古和俄罗斯国防部长谢尔盖·绍伊古。 《华尔街日报》援引未透露姓名的官员的话称，但俄罗斯国内安全部门 FSB 得知了该计划，绍伊古和格拉西莫夫改变了行程。这迫使普里戈任提前行动，周五，他的瓦格纳部队控制了位于顿河畔罗斯托夫的俄罗斯南部军区总部，这是对乌克兰战争的重要后勤和指挥中心。

;

;美国官员告诉媒体，他们几天前就知道了计划中的起义，普里戈任从他的私人军队中派出一支部队前往莫斯科，然后放弃，因为总统弗拉基米尔·普京称该组织为“叛徒”

;

;《纽约时报》还援引未透露姓名的美国官员的话说，俄罗斯高级将军谢尔盖·苏罗维金事先就知道普里戈任的叛变计划。报道称，美国官员现在想查明苏罗维金是否可能协助了瓦格纳的计划。

;

;该报还写道，根据美国特工部门的信息，有迹象表明其他俄罗斯将军可能已经了解普里戈任的事情计划。

;

;据《泰晤士报》报道，美国官员认为，如果普里戈任不相信其他人会伸出援助之手，他就不会发动叛乱。

;

;被监禁的克里姆林宫批评家阿列克谢·纳瓦尔尼认为瓦格纳叛乱是一种“互联网迷因”

;

;克里姆林宫周三将《泰晤士报》关于苏罗维金的报道斥为“猜测”。

;

;“现在有很多不同的猜测和八卦据俄罗斯新闻机构报道，克里姆林宫发言人德米特里·佩斯科夫表示：“围绕这些事件。” “我认为这就是一个例子。”

;

;俄罗斯军队和该国人民“在起义期间都支持总统[弗拉基米尔·普京]”，佩斯科夫说。

;

;苏罗维金被认为是普里戈任的盟友，但周六晚上却站在了莫斯科的当权者一边。在视频信息中，苏罗维金呼吁普里戈任结束他的斗争。

;

;《泰晤士报》写道，美国高级官员怀疑苏罗维金和普里戈任之间的联盟可以解释为什么普里戈任在叛乱后仍然活着。< /p>;

;上周末的叛乱中，瓦格纳军队占领了俄罗斯南部城市顿河畔罗斯托夫，然后向莫斯科进军。

;

;与此同时，美国军事专家表示，白俄罗斯统治者亚历山大·卢卡申科可能会受益俄罗斯瓦格纳雇佣兵在他的国家，因为他们可能给他更多的空间来操纵克里姆林宫统治白俄罗斯的努力。

;

;白俄罗斯的普里戈任；普京称俄罗斯向瓦格纳集团支付了 10 亿美元

;

;总部位于华盛顿的战争研究所 (ISW) 晚间写道，有了瓦格纳军队驻扎在他的国家，卢卡申科可以更好地对抗普京吞并白俄罗斯的努力。周二。

;

;普京的亲密盟友卢卡申科表示，他在短暂的起义中在普京和普里戈任之间进行了调解，并说服后者投降。

;

;据报道，作为平息叛乱协议的一部分，普里戈任和他的战士已被流放到白俄罗斯。

;

;欧盟委员会于 6 月 15 日发布公告，被广泛报道为禁止中国电信公司华为和中兴通讯。相反，该通讯赞同一些成员国限制或完全排除这两家公司的行动，因为这符合欧盟关于 5G 安全的“工具箱”——一套旨在由成员国解释和实施的指导方针。

;

;一些欧盟国家效仿美国，将中国电信公司视为安全风险，而其他国家则没有，这表明政治因素可能在起作用。尽管当前欧盟圈子里在谈论“去风险”，但越来越多的趋势是将中国视为安全威胁，就像美国的辩论一样。然而，欧洲不是美国，可以从美中科技战的缓和中受益。

;

;多年来，中欧关系经历了波折，但经济利益通常会推动务实的做法。涉及贸易和投资。一些欧洲国家及其消费者已经接受了中国技术。

;

;另一方面，美国近年来采取了广泛的制裁和贸易壁垒行动来限制中国的技术产业，特别是禁止华为制裁超级计算机中心并阻止先进半导体接触中国工业客户。美国长期以来一直主导着全球科技产业，但现在在为正在进行的科技革命制定规范和规则方面有了竞争对手。

;

;从2017年开始，从特朗普政府开始，中国被视为关键国家安全威胁和战略竞争对手，尤其是华为。欧盟的一些政界现在正在呼应美国的立场。

;

;华为是 5G 无线和光纤电信网络及设备领域的全球领导者之一，但美国消息人士称其存在间谍风险。最近，美国表示担心华为积极参与全球标准制定扩大了中国的国家影响力并削弱了美国的影响力。

;

;没有任何证据（至少在公开记录上）表明华为有任何更大的影响力。安全风险或国家影响力的说法无法反驳。关于华为的争论的国家安全焦点可能会让我们忽视未来网络安全威胁实际上可能出现的地方，而风险可能出现在任何地方。

;

;长期以来，电信系统都面临着黑客攻击的风险。间谍活动或其他网络安全威胁不仅来自中国，还来自许多国家，以及恐怖组织、犯罪团伙甚至个人网络黑客等非国家行为者。

;

;所有电信运营商设备制造商和设备制造商都受到国家法律的约束，欧盟凭借其全面的网络安全法案、通用数据保护条例以及网络和信息安全指令，一直是制定新技术治理框架的领导者。其风险缓解措施包括加强监管权力，包括限制高风险供应商提供核心网络资产以及电信供应商多元化。

;

;在某些领域，中国在制定全球标准方面发挥着重要作用，例如高铁基础设施和自动驾驶汽车。然而，对于新的数字通信技术，目前还没有一套商定的全球规则，并且由于中美竞争的加剧而冻结了进展。在缺乏共同规则、规范和制度执行的情况下，技术的推出超出了我们为了社会利益而管理其使用的能力。

;

;当政客们谈论安全威胁时，电信行业参与者则专注于致力于为即将到来的高速通信、人工智能和云计算的融合开发基础设施、设备和服务，这将在未来十年改变各行各业和日常生活。

;

;华为是这些领域的全球领导者之一。字段。如果其创新能够在欧洲得到利用和安全管理，再加上欧洲公司的创新，数字连接不仅有望成为经济效率的主要贡献者，而且还将成为实现欧洲绿色协议的主要贡献者，数字化可以减少工业和环境的环境足迹。消费者也是如此。

;

;欧洲有一个选择。一方面，它可以加入美国对中国的科技战，冒着将世界分裂成两个互相武器化的技术民族主义领域的风险。在这种情况下，美国仍将主导其势力范围，但在某个阶段可能会被中国超越。另一方面，欧洲可以努力寻找理性、务实的解决方案来解决新技术带来的安全问题，将政治排除在争论之外。

;

;如果欧洲能够帮助建立一个供应商提供的网络安全系统——它是盲目的，并且采用世界其他国家可以实施的最佳实践，可以在缓和中美冲突方面发挥作用，从而确保全球化科技领域的未来更加安全。如果消费者既能从使用中国和美国技术中受益，又能保护自己的网络安全，那么欧洲人就可以两全其美。

;随着我们迈向后新冠时代，营销人员现在更看重品牌营销而非绩效营销，对营销效果和战略业务指标的关注变得越来越重要。

;

;研究表明，在后新冠时代，营销人员更加关注品牌营销以推动获取新客户并提高忠诚度、保留率和整体业务增长。

;

;;

;;巴特万豪国际集团亚太区首席销售和营销总监 Buiring 出席在香港举行的南华早报广告+首席营销官午餐会。;

;

;“我们看到我们的客户正在转型，他们的媒体从战术广告转向品牌主导的创意，因为这是增长的关键，”区域客户副总裁 Marilyn Yeong 说道大会。 “现在以品牌引领很重要。”

;;Marilyn Yeong，区域客户副总裁;

;

;“营销人员需要在学术上更强大，并拥有业务数据，如果仲量联行区域营销主管 Justin Bonnett 表示：“他们希望在董事会中得到更认真的对待。”

;

;“一个重要的结论是，65% 的受访者认为他们的竞争对手在数据衡量方面做得更好，”参与这项研究的IAB HK执行委员会成员Victor Cheng说道。 “我只能得出结论，市场认为另一边的草总是更绿——绿得多。”

;“这不仅仅是信心。如果说有什么不同的话，那就是过去 10 年教会我们的是，我们需要保持敏捷，能够利用数据发现机会，并真正实现差异化。”《南华早报》战略与洞察总监 Paul Phillips 说道。 /p>;

; Wed, 28 Jun 2023 23:20:02 +0800 Chinese University says no opportunity given to scrutinise controversial Hong Kong private member’s bill to change council’s compositionhttps://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/education/article/3225814/chinese-university-says-no-opportunity-given-scrutinise-controversial-hong-kong-private-members-bill?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.28 23:13;
;;

;Chinese University has said it has not had the opportunity to properly consider a bill designed to restructure its governing body after a lawmaker who introduced the proposal said he had heard no objection from its members.

;

;Tommy Cheung Yu-yan, a Liberal Party Legislative Council and Executive Council member who advises Chief Executive John Lee Ka-chiu, said on Wednesday he had reached a consensus with the city leader to push ahead with an overhaul of the body.

;

;The private member's bill from Cheung, who also sits on the university council, was designed to amend the Chinese University of Hong Kong Ordinance and is expected to have its first reading in the Legislative Council on Thursday.

;

;But the university said the council had not been given a final draft of the private bill before it reached Legco.

;

;“CUHK does not have a position on the private members bill as it has not been formally given the opportunity to consider it,” a spokeswoman said.

;

;She added the text of the lawmakers' bill “was not submitted to the council for discussion prior to it being gazetted” earlier this month.

;

;“The university council considered a task force report at its April meeting and the report determined that the 2016 model remained fit for purpose,” the spokeswoman said.

;

;Cheung's bill, if approved, would result in the downsizing of the council from 55 to 34 members and the ratio of staff members to external representatives would drop from about 1:1 to 1:2.

;

;It also has a provision to raise the voting threshold for the appointment of the university vice-chancellor from two-thirds to three-quarters of the council votes.

;

;The task force proposal recommended downsizing the council to 29, with internal members holding 11 seats and external ones 18 places.

;

;The task force was formed by the university council in the wake of the controversial proposal by Cheung, backed by fellow lawmakers Bill Tang Ka-piu and Edward Lau Kwok-fan, who also sit on the body.

;

;Cheung told reporters on Wednesday that he had been showing the proposal to the university council since last November and maintained that he had not heard any opposition.

;

;“If you ask the council, there's no one who doesn't know what we're doing unless they don't want to read it,” Cheung said. “I'm absolutely sure that I haven't heard anyone objecting.”

;

;University trio slam request to pay cost of Hong Kong private member's bill

;

;But he admitted the university council had not vetted the bill clause by clause.

;

;Cheung maintained if the restructuring process was left to the council it would take up to five years to materialise, but the use of a private member's bill would cut the time to one year.

;

;He insisted the bill was designed in line with the report's recommendations, but some council members have made their disagreement clear.

;

;Three council members, in an open letter released last week, slammed the lawmakers' proposal, which would retain three Legco representatives in the scaled down council, but reduce the number of those drawn from other areas.

;

;Enders Lam Wai-hung, one of the three authors of the letter, all Chinese University graduates appointed from the university's convocation, said they had made counter proposals last year when the lawmakers first floated their proposal.

;

;The task force's consultation also showed strong disapproval of the lawmakers' plan.

;

;“It is not accurate to say nobody has opposed their proposal,” he said.

;

;Sources familiar with the situation told the Post that the council had tried to convene a special meeting next month in response to a request from the letter writers to discuss Cheung's bill.

;

;One of the sources said if Legco decided to set up a bill committee to examine the proposal, others might be able to express their views and influence the outcome of the restructuring.

;

;Hong Kong lawmaker wants university to cover costs of private bid to revamp council

;

;The trio of lawmakers has also asked the university to reimburse them about HK$750,000 (US$95,754) to cover the costs of gazetting the bill as part of the required legislation process.

;

;Cheung said a separate fee for the introduction of a private member's bill was waived by the authorities.

;

;The chief secretary for administration can cancel the fee if a bill “facilitates a government measure.”

;

;Cheung added Lee had told him the administration would be unable to prioritise changes at the university council because of a busy schedule of legislation proposals.

;

;“The only, fastest way was for us to work on this private bill instead of going through the government,” he said.

;

;Lee has given his consent to the private member's bill in line with the Basic Law, the city's mini constitution, which allows lawmakers to introduce proposed legislation not related to public spending, political structure or government operations.

;

;Lee said last Tuesday that permission was given “in accordance with the laid-down procedures” and that Legco would deal with the bill according to “such rules and procedures”.

;

;The three lawmakers' move was seen as the pro-establishment bloc's response to the controversial reappointment of Professor Rocky Tuan Sung-chi, who will stay on as university president until 2026.

;

;Tuan was accused by some pro-Beijing figures of being sympathetic to protesting students during the 2019 social unrest.

; Wed, 28 Jun 2023 23:20:02 +0800 Beijing official’s warning of ‘soft confrontations’ not relevant in sedition trial of former Stand News editors, defence tells courthttps://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/law-and-crime/article/3225810/beijing-officials-warning-soft-confrontations-not-relevant-sedition-trial-former-stand-news-editors?utm_source=rss_feed

;A Beijing official's warning against “soft confrontations” in Hong Kong after the national security law took effect should not form part of a sedition case against two former chief editors at a now-closed news outlet, defence lawyers have told a court.

;

;The defence also urged the District Court not to hold the pair from Stand News liable for the extremist thoughts and independence agendas that Xia Baolong, director of the State Council's Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Office, had said persisted after the law's imposition in 2020.

;

;They added that none of the articles published on the popular website posed a substantial risk to the country's safety.

;

;Wednesday's remarks came on the third and last day of oral submissions from the bar table as the trial drew to a close, after stretching 35 days past its original schedule of 20 days.

;

;Former editors-in-chief Chung Pui-kuen, 53, and Patrick Lam Shiu-tung, 35, face a joint conspiracy charge for allegedly conspiring to publish and reproduce seditious publications to damage the central government, the local administration and the national security law.

;

;The court also recorded a not guilty plea from Best Pencil HK, Stand News' holding company, which is unrepresented in the proceedings.

;

;Prosecutors initially relied on 17 writings critical of Beijing and the Hong Kong government as proof that Stand News had instigated hatred and contempt towards authorities.

;

;But they have since expanded the case to cover 587 other articles previously ignored by investigators, as part of accusations that Stand News conducted biased reporting and advocated anti-government beliefs.

;

;Ex-chief editor denies Stand News promoted 'radical' Hong Kong opposition, court hears

;

;Prosecutors said the hundreds of reports, which feature criticisms of the national security law and the Chinese Communist Party, showed the news agency's intent to steer public opinion in favour of the opposition when it ran the original 17 stories between July 2020 and December 2021.

;

;A prosecution filing cited an address earlier this year by Xia, who said the city should remain vigilant against “soft confrontations” and “anti-China activities carried out under the guise of so-called human rights, freedom, democracy and livelihood”.

;

;Lead prosecutor Laura Ng Shuk-kuen asked the court to convict the defendants in light of Xia's statement, noting that Stand News had run the provocative reports even as hidden forces continued to threaten national security.

;

;But Ng's opponent, senior counsel Audrey Eu Yuet-mee, argued that Xia was merely commenting on the city's current sociopolitical situation instead of targeting the now-defunct news outlet.

;

;“We find it very difficult to understand the prosecution's argument [that Xia's statement] is evidence because he is an expert on national security,” Eu told Judge Kwok Wai-kin, who was approved by city leader John Lee Ka-chiu to hear the case.

;

;The senior counsel said prosecutors had also failed to identify the national security risk posed by the 17 stories which formed the backbone of their case.

;

;“We, the media, are obliged to reflect the views of third parties. You cannot convict us based on what we said because we failed to sever ties with them,” she said.

;

;Stand News did not censor bloggers with 'radical' Hong Kong views, court hears

;

;The prosecution also pointed to 45 separate court cases, some of which are still ongoing, that were potentially influenced by online media.

;

;Eu asked the judge to discard that piece of “prejudicial” information and highlighted the lack of evidence that the accused in those cases had been galvanised by Stand News' publications.

;

;The court is expected to hand down its ruling on October 4.

;

;Sedition is punishable by up to two years imprisonment for a first conviction under local legislation.

;

;The Court of Final Appeal has regarded the offence as one capable of endangering national security, and cases can only be heard by arbiters approved by the chief executive.

;Premier Li Qiang has called for multinational corporations to step up their game in investing in China's tech and scientific innovation sectors, as foreign businesses continue to seek assurances from Beijing over a raft of concerns.

;

;Li and more than 120 business representatives exchanged some of their most pressing concerns and requests during a closed-door meeting that took place this week on the sidelines of the three-day annual World Economic Forum, often referred to as the “Summer Davos”, in the northern Chinese city of Tianjin.

;

;“We are willing to work with all parties in the push to develop cutting-edge technology, create new areas for cooperation, and open up new space for business investment,” Li told business representatives from more than 20 countries and regions, in a meeting on Tuesday afternoon when the forum kicked off, according to an official Chinese readout.

;

;Li said China could promise “great opportunities for cooperation” as it is set to achieve “breakthroughs in the new round of science and tech industrial revolution” by strengthening innovation in science and tech, building a modernised industrial system and boosting domestic demand.

;

;Premier plays up China's economic outlook, hits out at West over 'de-risking'

;

;The Chinese statement also said Li responded to business representatives' questions regarding corporate cooperation, data management and climate change.

;

;Li's invitation for foreign companies' participation in tech and science sectors came as Beijing faces a major bottleneck in the development in these areas, including telecommunications, semiconductors and aircraft, as it deals with debilitating restrictions in an intense tech rivalry with Washington.

;

;Li, who has been driving China's economic policy since March, has also been repeating rhetoric to lure foreign investment to China as the country attempts to recover from its years-long zero-Covid policy.

;

;Yet, foreign business representatives in the meeting with Li said they hoped to see further reassurances from the Chinese government.

;

;Ralf Brandstaetter, CEO of German carmaker Volkswagen Group in China, said in the meeting that companies need more clarity on cross-border data transfers, and he asked how China plans to cooperate with Europe amid rising political tensions.

;

;“As a globalised industry, the transformation of the automotive sector highly depends on the international exchange of personnel, data and knowledge. We, therefore, need more clarity on cross-border data transfers,” the executive said, according to Reuters. And he reportedly added: “What are the major considerations of China, and how will China cooperate with Europe in this regard?”

;

;Michael Hart, president of the American Chamber of Commerce in China, said that while data protection is a cross-industry concern for its members, many companies face other deterring factors when considering investing in China.

;

;“Companies are very pleased to hear that sort of macro-welcomeness. One of the questions though, is that there are still restrictions on certain types of investments. When we surveyed our members, they told us that they would be willing to invest more in China if industries weren't restricted,” Hart said. “In some areas, like even financial services, which in theory is open, there's still a long process to actually make this happen.”

;

;China's new premier, Li Qiang, takes pro-private sector campaign on the road

;

;Beijing made promises earlier this year to relax its entity list that prohibits foreign firms deemed “unreliable entities” from engaging in import, export and investment in China, as part of its confidence-boosting campaign to assure foreign investors that China would continue to open its market. But there have yet to be major changes announced in this area.

;

;Meanwhile, Chinese companies may face further limitations in their access to foreign technology, while foreign companies could face increasing uncertainties regarding investing in these areas in China, as the US and European governments insist that they need to “de-risk” their supply chain.

;

;The European Economic Security Strategy, unveiled by Brussels last week and to be discussed further this week at an annual two-day summit, would potentially restrict autocratic governments' access to European technologies that are seen as key to economic security, such as quantum computing and artificial intelligence.

;

;Foxconn chairman Liu Young-Way, who spoke on the panel about Asia's manufacturing resurgence at the World Economic Forum, said that a shift in the industrial chain from higher-GDP to lower-GDP countries is inevitable, but added that this should not be seen as further confrontation.

;

;“What China needs to do is to create more value and transform and upgrade its industry,” said Liu, from Apple's biggest iPhone maker. “I think the international community should now place greater emphasis on sharing cooperation and common prosperity. I hope sharing will not turn into closure and cooperation will not turn into confrontation.”

;

;Separately, Liu told Chinese tabloid Global Times that Apple has no plans to move its supply chain completely out of China.

;

;Yet, the Taiwanese manufacturer earlier announced it would ramp up investment outside China, such as in India, to meet customer demand and lower its reliance on China for production.

;

;Raids, restrictions and the art of woo: how US-China trade hangs in the balance

;

;Hart, who heads AmCham China, said that apart from companies' top concerns over geopolitical relations between China and the US, recent economic data from China does not help boost confidence from foreign investors.

;

;“I would just say the things that people look at are signals, if it was consumer spending, consumer competence, private investment. None of those things seem to be signalling a rapid rebound, and that is making people a bit hesitant,” Hart said.

;

;However, Hart noted that industries that are less affected by geopolitical tensions, such as healthcare and food and beverages, still appear to be more interested than others in investing in China due to the long-term consideration of market size.

;

;China's latest economic data on May released earlier this month showed industrial output and retail sales growth missed market expectations.
